awd_titl_txt: RUI: Efficient Numerical Methods for Axisymmetric Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
An axisymmetric problem is a problem defined on a three-dimensional (3D) domain that is symmetric with respect to an axis. These problems arise in various applications in the field of biomedical engineering, electromagnetism, and optics. An axisymmetric problem can be reduced to a sequence of two-dimensional (2D) problems by using cylindrical coordinates and a Fourier series decomposition. A discrete problem corresponding to a 2D problem is significantly smaller than a discrete problem corresponding to a 3D one, so such dimension reduction is an attractive feature considering computation time. The resulting 2D problem, however, is posed in weighted function spaces and is mathematically quite different from the analogous "standard" 2D problems, so special care is required when developing numerical methods that are well-fit for these weighted 2D problems. In this project, we will study efficient numerical techniques with solid mathematical support that can be applied to axisymmetric problems including those that arise in the treatment of various cancer treatments.  
 
The first goal of this project is to perform multigrid analysis for axisymmetric H(curl) and H(div) problems with general data including the axisymmetric time harmonic Maxwell equations. Multigrid for axisymmetric H(curl) and H(div) problems have been studied previously under the assumption that the data is independent of the rotational variable, which is not the case for most applications. Therefore, this project will bring new results for general axisymmetric problems with meaningful applications in Hepatic Microwave Ablation, an alternate treatment to liver, breast, bone, and lung cancer. Undergraduate students will be a part of evaluating the performance of multigrid in designing efficient antennas that can be used for these cancer treatments. Furthermore, this project will provide new mathematical tools to study axisymmetric problems with general data as well.  The second goal of this project is to study axisymmetric state-constrained elliptic optimal control problems with axisymmetric data by using P1 finite element methods. There are very few studies done on axisymmetric optimal control problems, so this will be new and significant. The PI will also run a "Numerical Analysis Day" for local high school students with her undergraduate students from the James Madison University Association for Women in Mathematics Student Chapter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
An axisymmetric problem is a problem defined on a three-dimensional (3D) domain that is symmetric with respect to an axis. For example, the electromagnetic distribution from an axisymmetric antenna can be model through the Maxwell equations defined on an axisymmetric domain. By using cylindrical coordinates and a Fourier series decomposition, 3D axisymmetric problems can be reduced to a sequence of two-dimensional (2D) problems. The study of axisymmetric problems and their discretizations is important, since the computation time saved by such kind of dimension reduction is significant. In this project, we construct and analyze efficient numerical methods that can be applied to 2D problems arising from axisymmetric problems. 

In this project, the PI used a family of Fourier finite element spaces that they previously constructed to discretize the axisymmetric Hodge Laplacian problems. Stability and convergence results were verified for these spaces, and these results were used to further study a multigrid algorithm that can be applied to axisymmetric H(div) and H(curl) problems. Multigrid is an efficient iterative technique that can be applied to solve matrix systems, and the uniform convergence results of the multigrid V-cycle with respect to meshsize for these axisymmetric problems have been established in this project. Furthermore, the multigrid algorithm has also been applied to antenna designs for Hepatic Microwave Ablation, where a small probe is used to kill cancer cells to treat liver cancer. In this project, PI and collaborators also studied elliptic state-constrained optimal control problems and their discretizations on both axisymmetric and general domains. The research plan outlined in the initial grant proposal was closely followed throughout the project, and all objectives for the Intellectual Merit have been achieved. 

Six articles have been published and/or submitted as a part of this project all in peer-reviewed and well-established journals. Preprints are available on the PI's webpage and on arXiv. All codes resulting from this research are available on the PI's or the PI's students' GitHub page. The results from this project were presented at many professional conferences and university colloquiums/seminars. The PI also gave the invited afternoon address at the Fall 2021 MAA MD-DC-VA Sectional Meeting and was invited to attend the a Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach Workshop on Hilbert Complexes: Analysis, Applications, and Discretizations in Summer 2022. 

As for the Broader Impacts, the PI integrated their research into the classroom and supervised four undergraduate research students at JMU through this project. One student extended the Fourier finite element spaces previously constructed by the PI to higher-order and applied them to the axisymmetric Hodge Laplacian problems and got promising results. This work was published in SIAM Undergraduate Research Online and was also included in their 75-page Honors Thesis. Furthermore, this student presented their work at the MAA MD-DC-VA Section Meeting in Spring 2021, and won the first prize student poster presentation award. Two other JMU undergraduate research students worked on constructing new finite element methods for the axisymmetric elliptic state-constrained optimal control problems with general data. A well-documented report of their work is available on the PI's website. Their work was recently completed by another JMU undergraduate student who gave a presentation at the 2023 Spring MAA MD-DC-VA Section Meeting and won the First Prize Presentation Award. These students got successful careers after graduation such as a software engineer at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and a gradaute student in applied mathematics at North Carolina State University. The PI was also one of the faculty organizers of a large-scale Research Experience for Undergraduates, Summer@ ICERM 2020: Fast Learning Algorithms for Numerical Computation and Data Analysis at Brown University. This work also led to student publications and presentations. Two of the students that the PI advised in this program are currently in graduate school at Standford University and Emory University, and both received an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. 

The PI also started an annual outreach event called Girls' Math and Coding Day at JMU in Spring 2020. In this NSF-funded outreach event, local female high school students from the Advancement Via Individual Determination (AVID) program attend a coding workshop developed by the PI and assisted by students from the JMU Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) Student Chapter. The high school students also attend several research talks by female applied math professors at JMU, and have lunch with professors and students from the AWM Student Chapter and the Haynes Scholars Program. The PI worked closely with the Chief Academic Officer and the STEM Director of the Harrisonburg City Public Schools to bring female students from the AVID program to this event. Most students in the AVID program are students that will become first generation college students and are students of color. This NSF-funded outreach event is well-accepted by the Harrisonburg community and was recognized by the Superintendent at the School Board meeting in June 2022. 


Last Modified: 09/18/2023
Modified by: Minah Oh
